[[Image:VMware Workstation 6 running ubuntu.png|260px|right|thumb|[[VMware Workstation]] running [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], on Windows, an example of ''Operating system-level virtualization'']]
+
[[Image:VMware Workstation 6 running ubuntu.png|260px|right|thumb|[[VMware Workstation]] running [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], on Windows, an example of ''Operating system-level virtualization'']]
In [[computing]], '''virtualization''' is a broad term that refers to the [[abstraction]] of computer resources. Virtualization hides the physical characteristics of computing resources from their users, be they [[application]]s, or [[end user]]s.<ref>{{ cite web | last = Turban | first = E | coathors = King D, Lee J, Viehland D | date = 2008 | title = Electronic Commerce A Managerial Perspective | edition = 5th edition | publisher = Prentice-Hall | chapter = Ch19 | pages = P27 | url = http://wps.prenhall.com/wps/media/objects/5073/5195381/pdf/Online_Chapter_19.pdf }}; {{ cite web | url = http://www-03.ibm.com/industries/education/doc/content/resource/thought/3371378110.html | title = Virtualization in education | publisher = [[IBM]] }}</ref> This includes making a single physical resource (such as a [[server (computing)|server]], an [[operating system]], an application, or [[storage device]]) appear to function as multiple virtual resources; it can also include making multiple physical resources (such as storage devices or servers) appear as a single virtual resource;<ref>{{Citation | last = Mann | first = Andi | title = The Pros and Cons of Virtualization | publisher = Business Trends Quarterly | url = http://www.btquarterly.com/?mc=pros-cons-virtualization&page=virt-viewresearch | accessdate = 2008-04-21}}; {{Citation | last = Mann | first = Andi | title = Virtualization 101 | publisher = Enterprise Management Associates (EMA) | url = http://www.emausa.com/ema_lead.php?ls=virtwpws0806&bs=virtwp0806 | accessdate = 2007-10-29}}</ref>
In [[computing]], '''virtualization''' is a broad term that refers to the [[abstraction]] of computer resources. Virtualization hides the physical characteristics of computing resources from their users, be they [[application]]s, or [[end user]]s.<ref>{{ cite web | last = Turban | first = E | coathors = King D, Lee J, Viehland D | date = 2008 | title = Electronic Commerce A Managerial Perspective | edition = 5th edition | publisher = Prentice-Hall | chapter = Ch19 | pages = P27 | url = http://wps.prenhall.com/wps/media/objects/5073/5195381/pdf/Online_Chapter_19.pdf }}; {{ cite web | url = http://www-03.ibm.com/industries/education/doc/content/resource/thought/3371378110.html | title = Virtualization in education | publisher = [[IBM]] }}</ref> This includes making a single physical resource (such as a [[server (computing)|server]], an [[operating system]], an application, or [[storage device]]) appear to function as multiple virtual resources; it can also include making multiple physical resources (such as storage devices or servers) appear as a single virtual resource;<ref>{{Citation | last = Mann | first = Andi | title = The Pros and Cons of Virtualization | publisher = Business Trends Quarterly | url = http://www.btquarterly.com/?mc=pros-cons-virtualization&page=virt-viewresearch | accessdate = 2008-04-21}}; {{Citation | last = Mann | first = Andi | title = Virtualization 101 | publisher = Enterprise Management Associates (EMA) | url = http://www.emausa.com/ema_lead.php?ls=virtwpws0806&bs=virtwp0806 | accessdate = 2007-10-29}}</ref>
